review_title: It truly is a modern day plantation
pros: None. It just helped me lose weight But that's it. If.
cons:
Beware to the people who wish to work here. It is NOT the rosy amazing picture that some people try so hard to paint. Despite being Heaven for the blissfully unaware customers that receive their packages anonymously by Amazon, it's absolute Hell every day for the low level grunts such as the stowers and pickers on the floor who gets it to them. You're only seen as a mule or a robot to the floor managers and other higher ups above you. You have no name there except for the i.d numbers that come up whenever they scan your badge, and you're in constant crippling pain all while you're there because of the extreme quotas, unrealistic expectations, and hard labor you're forced to do. The machinery and robots are treated more humane than we are. 

Nobody truly listens when you genuinely need help with something, and you're always being heavily monitored by floor managers and higher ups every second of the day from when you come in to when you leave, in hopes of catching even the littlest slip up you may do. If they're not doing that, then they're hounding you every 3 minutes about your speed on scanning items...every 10 seconds we have to easily scan EVERYTHING perfectly with no problems. Even the heavy giant items that take a long time to squeeze into the yellow pods.

There are so many other things wrong with these warehouses, that it's a really a wonder how Jeff Bezos didn't get caught and hanged by a lynch mob yet! But all I'll say is if i wasn't so desperate to make enough quick cash to move far away from my crazy narcissistic room mate forever then I been would've quit this insane asylum the 3rd day. I've been here 3 months now which is a miracle. I really hope it gets better for me eventually.

review_title: Ok But not a work you can do for the rest of your life

cons: The worst schedule ever, you can work from 6am to 00:00 8hr or 10 hrs shift with one hour unpaid lunch break. The 10hr shift is terrible, autumnal months are infernal, very busy and a lot of angry customers. There are also a lot of good and kind understandable people but those who are angry oh my god, it s so exhausting. Don’t apply if you’re “weak” and you don’t have patience. I've found all my colleagues to be clever, engaging and thoughtful people - determined to do the right thing and instill both quality and innovation in their work ethos!
cons: The hiring process is an excellent and enjoyable experience (something you can rarely say about large companies!), however the onboarding experience was quite disorientating --  largely due to starting from home working and needing to find information online in internal systems. pros: Working from home during the pandemic meant independence in managing my tasks. As long as your targets are met at the end of the week, you can decide how you organize your work (unofficially), since no manager is there to micro manage and give you anxiety.
cons:
1. Having to track every minute of my time at work in real time really ruined the experience for me. As someone with ADHD & anxiety who can't work while being watched, I could not focus on my tasks until I could log off the tracker. This led to me working at night sometimes. 

2. The culture is really toxic, especially with middle management throwing people in their teams under the bus and showing us they don't care about our wellbeing, only about the team's results and how that will make them look. I've had this happen with all 3 managers I had in as many teams, so it's not just some subjective/personal I have. What makes it worse is the gaslighting and their pretending nothing is wrong and expecting everyone to do the same. 

3. It would have been nice to get some kind of reimbursement for the utilities since we work from home. 

4. There is no structured/organized/professional internal training. Most of it are presentations read by a slow automated voice, and we can't even change the audio speed. Apart from the technical aspect, every person on the team knows something different, and it could be months before you finally find out something important that no one thought to tell you about. I don't think this is intentional, but I do believe they are unprepared and unprofessional in this aspect. 

5. The company boasts its diversity policies, but at an individual level, team mates will still make sexist and homophobic comments and jokes to which even managers laugh along. This is inappropriate and alienating, and it caused me to choose not to engage with the team more than the job requires. I am not sure any amount of training will do any good considering the combination of the company culture + the deep-rooted sexism and homophobia in Romanian tradition. 

6. This might be a pro for some, but it looks like recently they will hire anyone regardless of qualifications. Most of my team barely speaks decent English, when the required level for the job is advanced/near native. This wouldn't be such a problem if they weren't allowed to write training materials/be in charge of auditing /explaining important matters. It's a very frustrating experience, since not even asking them to switch to Romanian will help the issue, as they don't have sufficient knowledge to pass it to others. The company seems to be prioritizing quantity over quality and hiring unprepared people. When they cannot do their job properly, the rest of the team has to take over, yet we are the ones sanctioned if targets are not met.

pros: Great benefits with competitive pay. You will work with some of the smartest and most talented people in the industry from all over the world. As long as you can regularly invent and simplify and deliver results you will maintain good job security. Due to fast pace growth and expansion the job is never boring and constantly changing. Career opportunities are never ending as long as you are producing in your current role. If you perform well in your reviews you will most likely get additional restricted stock units.
cons: You will never be able to disconnect from work. You will be expected to have communication apps put on your phone and you will be contacted all the time no matter how much you plan otherwise(Vacation, Sick, bereavement, weekends, 24 hours). The company has 14 leadership principles that matter differently depending on what you are doing. Most of these are embodied in corporate roles but in operation only delivering results really matters. Fast pace growth is awesome for job security but leads to a culture of employees at all levels that change/move so frequently that team building is almost impossible. You will have to rebuild teams at best every quarter at worst every 2weeks. Rank stacking review model, so no matter how good or bad your location is someone is always on their way out and some one is always on there way up weather they earned it or not. Ambiguity is high and never ending which makes standards/best practices a suggestion more than a requirement. Movement of job title, category, and location can be changed regularly without warning. Due to the high movement and strong focus on delivering results you should not expect for any of the senior leadership to engage you in anything other than delivering results. There is no structure anywhere in the company for rotation of shifts. There is high likelihood the longer you work for the company the more you will work overnights and weekends with no choice. You will not get annual bonuses past sign on and some role launches you can only potentially get a nominal base pay increase and maybe restricted stock units with a great review. Total compensation has not maintained past sign on bonuses/stocks unless you promote for anyone I know. Most people only maintain and increase in pay slightly with promotions unless they promote very quickly. So everyone I know that has not promoted at least once before their sign on benefits wore off lost a significant amount of money in total compensation. Longevity with the company earns you nothing and provides you with no additional benefits other than more vacation over time that caps out.

pros: The company is ever growing, but everyone knows that. There is opportunity for lateral movement within different business types in the company. Great opportunity to gain skills and professional network.
cons: Long hours, I usually worked 55-60 hour work weeks on assigned work days and was always on call on days off. Which meant I was also working from home on my days off for about 6-7 years straight. I missed major Holidays, Birthdays, and major life events with family and friends because of the schedule you work for this company. I worked every Thanksgiving for the past 9.5 years I was with Amazon, missed Christmas and New Years for the past 8 years because of my schedule with the company. It was impossible to request time off to travel during these times because of "schedule black out" times or "business need" telling me I was too valuable on the work floor the day before/of/after. Promotions are abundant, but from what I observed in my later years promos mostly fell into a favoritism scale. No monthly bonuses, but there is annual reviews twice a year. These reviews are based on a multitude of gradings on you as a leader. These reviews decides if you're "ready" for a promotion, getting a raise, staying at same salary with the possibility of stock attainment, or receiving the dreaded Performance Improvement Plan (which basically means start looking for another job). Receiving stocks used to be great when I started with the company. My first set of stocks given time in the company was 300 share units, by my last year with the company the max given to salary managers was 2. Stocks have a vestment time as well from anywhere between 2-4 years. That means you don't actually get the stocks until you work for the company in good standing until those 2-4 years from grant date is up. So the last 2 shares granted to me had a vestment time of 2 years, 1 of those shares was sold to pay the taxes on the vestment, and the other share roughly came to a $500 bonus a year for the total vestment. Towards the end of my career with the company I saw too much movement of Sr Leadership, which meant my development started over with each new leader. This caused loss opportunities for promotions within the company, because new leaders didn't know their teams well enough during review times. I loved the teams I worked with, met some amazing people, and gained tremendous experience to further my professional career, but because of the type of Sr Leadership I was exposed to in my later years I decided to leave only 6 months shy of my 10 year anniversary with the company.

pros: You get to meet people of all walks of life, it has a very interesting and diverse work force which is great to get to know. They pay is decent for trying to get by in the Greater Seattle Area. Have some fun games or minor motivation to work to distract yourself, which helps a lot.
cons: Lots of Small physical tasks that will ultimately destroy your body. You are never praised for any work you do unless you are the top 1%, and trying to get yourself there is going to result in you hurting yourself. They offer a care center in which they will try to push off your injury as not their fault, but will offer some things to possibly help in the future, but then will just throw you back on the line. Breaks are very short and heavily controlled. Everyone takes a break at the same time, and you better hope your station is close to a break room other wise you will spend 7 minutes walking back and forth from the break room to your station, and get to enjoy 3 minutes of sitting down. All you will ever be told is to go faster, even if you are above average, you should go faster. Probably one of my least favorite parts is that people are punished if there is no work to do. If there are to many people working for a day, and you need to stay to get paid, your productivity goes down, and it is your fault, and will get you into trouble with management as your numbers do not look good. That is all you will ever feel like here, a number, not a person. Management feels like they have to fake care, there is always the corporate answer, which you can tell most supervisors do not like, but have to say.

job_title: Fulfillment Center Lead in Reading, PA
pros: Generally, a good place to work. Fair compensation, decent benefits package, lots of bonuses (small, but appreciated). Expectations from management for production were reasonable (if you don't mind working, but that's another story). A good fit for the right type of person.
cons:
These far outweigh the Pros. 

The workforce wasn't the least bit motivated. I watched as people who were paid the same as I was would spend most of their time talking with others, sneaking in phone calls, and spending most of their energy trying to look like they were working. Many people were simply bored by the monotony of many of the tasks, and those of us who wanted to contribute found ourselves trying to find things to do.

Poor management across the board. I found only two people who seemed to have their heads screwed on straight, but both were incapable of following up on anything that I discussed with them, Zero action, and that's not an exaggeration.

The company policies, especially in HR, were generally counterproductive and the answers to simple questions were inconsistent. Good people went running for the door across the board.

As an example, I had a very high rating for productivity, never had a sick day or was late, and when I relocated to another state, I was treated like dirt. I was offered four positions over many months. One was an overnight shift (which I told them I didn't want, and the other three were all offered and then rescinded, each time for a different policy reason. And to make it worse, the benefits that I had earned would not carry over. I was just someone else who walked in the door.

pros: Lots of good people, they try,,,, covid testing, PE available everywhere, they really do try. For students or someone that take advantage of the VET (voluntary extra time), it is a good gig for them. Lots of students and second jobbers
cons: Next to no communications. You show up to work, and until they yell "clock out", you have no idea if your on a +1 hour shift, or a -1 hour shift. You learn to guess based on when they call break. Totally unnecessary. Training is for your job specifically (sorter, puller, etc) but you learn little about the overall company and where your function exist in the system - therefor little visibility to the world of possible carrier wise. Pay is decent. Oh, and Holidays... forget about them. Christmas is just another work day. Probably the thing that will make me quit. They have no flexibility in their system enabling them to run light or split shifts. Its an all or nothing system. Also, many years ago I worked as a sorter at UPS during college. Were talking decades ago, and UPS at that time ran a cleaner operation. You can tell this is a fast growing organization with not enough experience running it. Little things like logistics for employees... facility doesn't have enough parking so parking is done off site. You have to arrive almost an hour before shift to get a spot. Then another half hour after to get a spot on the buss back to your car. A lot of growing pains. Same problem with enough trailers... stuff sits on the docs cluttering them up because they can't get trailers scheduled in. So you move things multiple times trying to find space to stage palettes. If you can put up with stuff like this... they will keep you busy... and paid decently
